1.7 Project Scale and Estimated GHG Emission Reductions or Removals
As per VCS guidance on REDD projects (VCS AFOLU v3 3.1.9), ex ante estimates to determine project scale
are provided for only the first 10-year baseline period, through November 2023 (Table 1.4). The project is
beneath the threshold of mega projects, with less than 1,000,000 tCO e per year in anticipated emissions 2
reductions generated.
Table 1.4. Ex ante estimates of net emission reductions (not including non-permanence risk buffer
deduction).
* Hereafter, the year refers to the year at the end of the annual interval, hence 2004 represents the
year from 4 November 2003 to 3 November 2004.

The project activity has not been rejected under any other GHG programs as this project activity
is using the new proposed methodology.

Eligibility Criteria
The project eligibility criteria are not applicable as the project activity is not a grouped project.
Leakage Management
As per new proposed methodology, no leakage will be occurred from the project activity.
Commercially Sensitive Information
No commercially sensitive information has been excluded from the public version of the project
description.
Further Information
Not applicable as relevant legislative, technical, economic, sectoral, social, environmental,
geographic, site-specific and/or temporal information have been defined in other relevant
sections.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
The project boundary encompasses also the project electricity system(s) and Heat/steam
generation system that the PO plant is connected to. The spatial extent of the project electricity
system consists of the power plants that are physically connected through transmission and
distribution lines to the project activity and that can be dispatched without significant transmission
constraints. The project is connected to the Glow grid which in turn is connected to the national
grid. Therefore, the national grid is considered as the ultimate connected grid. The spatial extent
for the heat (steam) system is similar, including the heat/steam generating systems that are
physically connected to the project activity and that can be displaced without significant
constraints. The heat (steam) requirements of the project are met by the steam extracted from the
cogeneration plants of Glow grid. As the emissions get accounted in the electricity component
therefore to avoid double counting and applying conservative principle the emission factor for
steam has been considered as zero. The fuel requirement is for incineration purpose. Natural gas
is being used as the fuel.
For the CHPO-chlor-alkali process (baseline scenario), the spatial extent of the project boundary
is defined as follows:

The crediting period starts with the commissioning of the plant, exactly with the first day of documented
electricity supply to the grid. There is no indication, that relevant transmission constraints divide the
national Turkish grid into regional subgrids, which had to separately be evaluated5.

Operation of:

o Kirpilik is expected in April 2010
The estimated emission reductions from the first and last year of the crediting period sum up to the
amount of the estimated yearly reductions.

period. It should be measured by using closed chamber in three reference fields which are

According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU
Methodology, the following requirements should be met.
1. The implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the involvement of
experts in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts (i.e. from research
institutions). These guidelines cannot replace expertise in setting up chamber measurements.
They rather set minimum requirements that serve for standardizing the conditions under
which methane emissions are measured for projects under this methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by experts
from Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences under the jurisdiction of the Anhui Agricultural
Bureau. Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences is a comprehensive agricultural research

Comparing the AEG and 20% of AEG , it is seen that 20% of AEG , is higher than SET-5-units TOTAL TOTAL
AEG SET-5-units.
Thereforethe 20% of AEG with a value of 39,198.54 GWh is to be compared to the capacity TOTAL
additions in the recent years.
Summing up electricity the generations of all the plants added to the Turkish National Grid in 2010
and 2009, but excluding the projects that claimed VERs, their total generation is 47,745.76 GWh.
The total generation by the power plants added in year 2010 is 26,256.04 GWh which is still less than
the 20% of AEG value of 39,198.54 GWh, however we are unable to identify the date of addition TOTAL
of the units that are added to the Grid in year 2009 to complete the amount of electricity added to the
Grid by year 2010 power plants. Therefore, with a conservative approach we are considering all the
units added in year 2009 and the AEG value we are using in our BM calculation is 47,745.76 SET Sample
GWh and is greater than the 20% of the total generation, So only the power plants added in the last 2
years, excluding those claiming VER credits, are used in the calculations. As there is no power unit
older than 10 years this number is being used for Build Margin Calculations.
The lists of most recent capacity additions to the grid by year and their average and firm generation
capacities for the years 2010, and 2009 are available as Annex-2 to the capacity projection reports
published in the TEIAS web page. Also the annual generation capacity data for each plant is not
available on the statistics page of TEƒ∞A≈û. The data for the years 200931 and 201032 are taken from
the TEƒ∞A≈û Capacity Projection Reports which are also available in another section of the TEƒ∞A≈û
website. For the capacity additions, the firm generation capacities of the power plants are used. The
units that are taken out of the grid are not taken into consideration. All the data used for calculations
could be found in Annex-2 (see Table 8a and Table8b).
According to the tool in terms of vintage of data, a project participant can choose either the ex-ante
option or the ex-post option. As explained above, out of these two options, Option 1 is selected. For
the first crediting period, the build margin emission factor is calculated ex-ante based on the most
recent information available on units already built for sample group m at the time of CDM-PDD
submission to the DOE for validation. For the second crediting period, the build margin emission
factor will be updated based on the most recent information available on units already built at the time
of submission of the request for renewal of the crediting period to the DOE. For the third crediting
period, the build margin emission factor calculated for the second crediting period will be used. This
option does not require monitoring the emission factor during the crediting period.
Electric efficiency rates
There is no complete and up-to-date data regarding the electrical efficiency of thermal power plants
that supply electricity to the Turkish National Grid system. Therefore the default values provided in
Annex 1(Default efficiency factors for power plants) of the Methodological Tool to calculate the
emission factor for an electricity system (Version 3.0.0) (EB 70, Annex 22) is utilised, in a very

1.11 Description of the Project Activity
From the total area, the first instance of the Carbon Project includes 1.159 ha of pure plantations
and 148 of silvopastoral systems. Forestal Azul will expand the area to at least to 1,805 ha,
including enrichment planting until 2021, however further expansion may occur in the future.
The project implementation/ plantation timeline of first instance plantations according to these
different systems is presented in the Table below. The corresponding annual operational plan
and the land use map for 2020 is presented in the Annex.
Table 1: Project land use and establishment plan of first instance plantations

4.4 Estimated Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
Long-term average
As part of an afforestation reforestation for commercial timber and rotation cycles, the
calculations have been done based on the AFOLU Requirements and guidance for calculating the
Long-Term Average Carbon Stock (LTA) for ARR Projects with Harvesting26, This includes all carbon
pools in the project.
The calculation of the LTA was made for each stratum, including above and belowground biomass,
SOC and excluding baseline, as presented in the table below. The complete tables for all ten
strata can be found in the Excel Ex-Ante San Pedro ‚Äì 1st project instance.
26 https://verra.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/VCS-Guidance-Harvesting-Examples_0.pdf

VCS Project Description Template
(Incorporating amendments made on 04/05/1994, 10/04/1997, 27/1/2000,
13/12/2000, 01/08/2001 and 21/11/2001) - S.O.60 (E), the project does not require
EIA submission36.
The project activity does not involve any major construction activity. It primarily
requires the installation of the Wind Electric Generators, interfacing the generators
with the Tamil Nadu Electricity Board, Hubli Electricity Supply Company Limited
(HESCOM) and Gulbarga Electricity Supply Company Limited (GESCOM) by setting
up HT transmission lines and installation of other accessories.
However, there are no negative impacts on air, water, soil quality and ambience are
envisaged due to the project activity.
6 Stakeholders comments:
Stakeholder Consultation meet was organized on 14/07/2009 at Suzlon Central
Monitoring Station (CMS) at Bogampatti village of Coimbatore,Tamil Nadu for M/s
Ram Kumar Mills and Mr R Kuppuswamy. For M/s. Vikram Traders the meeting was
organised on 18/08/2008 at the M/s. Suzlon site office Bagevadi village and Harogiri
village of Karnataka and for M/s. Mac Charles (India) Limited the meeting was on
23/08/2008 at M/s. Suzlon infrastructure services Ltd. Site office, harogiri village,
Gadag, Karnataka. The local villagers, site in charge, the maintenance personnel and
the land owners of the wind mill sites as the major stakeholders and all the
stakeholders were informed beforehand about the stakeholder consultation process
Comments of stakeholders were recorded during the stakeholder meeting.
The stake holder meeting process is followed in the following sequence
‚Ä¢ Election of the Chair of the meeting and approval of the proposed Agenda
‚Ä¢ Brief introduction of the brief introduction on climate change, global warming, Kyoto
protocol and the Voluntary Carbon Standard and role of local stake holder
‚Ä¢ Discussion and Articulation of concerns
‚Ä¢ Chair summarizing the local stake holder concerns
‚Ä¢ Vote of Thanks
The language used for the, interaction, sharing and responding to the questions was
in English, Tamil and Kannada. The summary of the meeting was recorded - copy of
which will be made available to Designated Operating Entity during validation
process. The list of participants with their signature is kept for record and
photographs of the event were also taken.

Calculation of Net Emissions Reductions
The annual net carbon emissions reductions is the actual net GHG removals by sinks from the project
scenario minus the net GHG removals by sinks from the baseline scenario, were then calculated by
applying the leakage and uncertainty discount factors (but not the VCS permanence buffer), on an
annualized basis:
ER = ER - LE (58) y y,GROSS y
Where,
ER = the net GHG emissions reductions and/or removals in year y (the overall annual carbon change y
between the baseline and project scenarios, net all discount factors except the permanence buffer) (t
CO e yr-1). 2
ER =the difference in the overall annual carbon change between the baseline and project y,GROSS
scenarios (t CO e yr-1). 2
LE = Leakage in year y (t CO e yr-1), as calculated in equation 56b. y 2
This calculation occurs within the Afognak Carbon Model Spreadsheet, using the data shown in Table
12 and Table 13.
Calculation of Voluntary Credit Units (VCUs)
The number of VCU‚Äôs the Afognak carbon project generates as available for issuance and sale in year,
y (VCU ; t CO e yr-1), is calculated as: y 2
VCU = ER (cid:79)(cid:1)(cid:4)(cid:13)(cid:1)‚Äì ER ) ‚Äì BR (59) y y y,ERR y
Where,
ER = the net GHG emissions reductions and/or removals in year (t CO e yr-1), as calculated in equation y 2
58.
ER = the uncertainty factor for year, y, (calculated in Section 4.5), expressed as a proportion. y,ERR
BR = estimated VCU-equivalent tCO e issued to the VCS Buffer Pool in year, y, calculated using the y 2
latest version of the VCS Tool for AFOLU Non-Permanence Risk Analysis and Buffer (Voluntary
Carbon Standard, 2008c). BRy is calculated by multiplying the most current verified permanence risk
Buffer Withholding Percentage for the project by the change in carbon stocks (difference between
baseline and project scenario) for the project area.
The VCS Buffer Discount Factor (BR ) was calculated as 13%, as per the non-permanence risk Y
assessment in Appendix 1. The BR factor will be re-assessed at each verification as necessary.
The uncertainty factor was conservatively estimated at 11.9%, as per Section 4.5. The uncertainty
factor will be re-calculated from field plot data at each verification.

Ex-ante estimates are provided in Table 13. below. These ex-ante estimates are for the entire
designated geographic area based on BEM estimates for the first PAI in Kamlapar. This assumes that
future PAIs will have similarly stocked forests and harvest areas to this first PAI, which may not be the
case due to uncertainty for future PAIs. However, per the methodology, ex-ante estimates are only
required to determine whether changes within carbon pools or increased GHG emissions due to project
activities are insignificant. As the project has only conservatively excluded selected pools such as SDW
and LDW will account for all significant emissions due to project activities, these ex-ante estimates are
only meant to provide potential crediting estimates across the project lifetime.
Estimated baseline emissions will change as future PAIs are added to the project. The addition of future
PAIs will require delineation of the area of the PAA as well as an inventory of carbon stocks within that
specific PAA. Thus, reported baseline emissions are only an estimate that assumes that future PAIs will
have similar areas and carbon stocks to the original PAI. This design for estimating ex-ante baseline
emissions across all PAIs is the same as was done for ex-ante project emissions (see Section 4.2.4).
Future reported baseline emissions will likely change significantly at verification events due to the
addition of new PAIs and inventory results. Project emissions will vary based on actual monitored
disturbances within each PAA.

Determination of EF BL, c
However, the baseline emission factor for continuously flooded fields without organic
amendments (EF ) can be determined ex-ante prior to the start of the project activity, in this BL,c
case, the ex-ante value should be used to calculate emission reduction during the crediting
period. It should be measured by using Closed Chamber in three reference fields which are
chosen in the project area.
According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU Methodology,
the implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the involvement of experts
in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts (i.e., from research institutions). These
guidelines cannot replace expertise in setting up chamber measurements. They rather set
minimum requirements that serve for standardizing the conditions under which methane
emissions are measured for projects under this methodology.
The Closed Chamber measurement requires the cooperation of the experts from Huazhong
Agricultural University and the staff of the Agricultural and Rural Committee of Dazu District.
Huazhong Agricultural University is a comprehensive agricultural research institution directly
under the provincial government. The expert set up the chamber measurements on 14-May-2017.
All the sample fields are in Sanqu Town, Dazu District. A total of 9 chambers were set up in three
baseline fields, three in each field. The base is embedded just before transplanting, and the first
gas sampling began on the second day after transplanting, followed by sampling every 7days.
After sampling, as is stored in the evacuated vial, and the samples collected after three times
should be taken together for laboratory analysis.
1) Project proponent shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane measurements
before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule for the field and laboratory
measurements, the logistics that are necessary to get the gas samples to the laboratory and
a cropping calendar. The plan shall also include all reference field specific information
regarding location and climate, soil, water management, plant characteristics, fertilizer
treatment and organic amendments.
19 For all scaling factor used in this methodology, the average values in 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
are chosen.

context:
2.1 Monitoring of carbon stock changes and GHG emissions associated to leakage prevention
activities
A reduction in carbon stocks due to activities carried out in leakage management areas is not
expected as no activities of agricultural improvement or management of grazing areas able to alter
carbon stocks and increase GHG emissions as compared with baseline scenario in leakage management
areas is planned to be implemented. However, if it is decided that such activities are necessary, then the
ex ante carbon stock changes and GHG emissions associated to such activities will be estimated as per
step 8 of the methodology VM0015, and if significant they will be monitored and data will be made
available to the verification body at each verification event using Tables 30b, 30c, 31, 32 and 33 of
methodology VM0015 version 1.1.
The following activities in leakage management areas could occasion a decrease in carbon stocks
or an increase in GHG emissions:
‚Ä¢ Carbon stock changes due to activities implemented in leakage management areas;
‚Ä¢ Methane (CH ) and nitrous oxide (N O) emissions from livestock intensification (involving 4 2
a change in the animal diet and/or animal numbers).
v3.1! 144

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
According to the most recent version of the VCS Standard nitrous oxide (N2O) emissions from
nitrogen fertilization are always considered insignificant. Consumption of fossil fuels is considered always
insignificant in AUD project activities and must not be considered.

6.5 Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
The total GHG emission reductions of the first project instances for the 1st monitoring period
30.09.2019 until 15.11.2020 are 1,694 tCO2e. The non-permanence risk rating is 15% (as
determined in the AFOLU non-permanence risk report attached as a separate document).
Therefore, the total number of buffer credits that need to be deposited into the AFOLU pooled
buffer account is 254 tCO2e. The number of GHG credits eligible to be issued as VCUs for the
first project instances of this monitoring period is 1,440 tCO2e. The current emission reductions
have not yet reached the Long-Term Average (1,694 tCO2e < 205,762 tCO2e).

The project activity reduces carbon dioxide emissions through displacement of grid electricity
generation with predominantly fossil fuel based power plants5 by renewable electricity. The
emission reduction ER y due to project activity during a given year y is estimated as the
difference between baseline emissions (BE ), project emissions (PE ) and emissions due to y y
leakage (L ), as per the formula given below: y
ER = BE ‚Äì PE - LE y y y y

3.4 Summary of GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
Ex ante total net anthropogenic GHG emission reductions (Step 9 VM0015 v1.0)
Significance Assessment (Step 9.1 VM0015 v1.0)
The sources of GHG emissions considered in the PCFS (above- and below-ground biomass - see Table 16
Methodology VM0015 v1.0) are significant, as demonstrated by applying the "Tool for Testing Significance of
GHG Emissions in A/R CDM Project Activities," where the above-ground biomass accounts for 74.5% of the
expected emissions in the baseline scenario and below-ground biomass accounts for the remaining
90

VCS Project Description Template
25.5%. Both sources, therefore, show a significance level >5% and thus will be considered in calculations of
reductions in net GHG emissions by project activities.
For the project baseline scenario, the significance level was calculated for potential emission sources as well
as activities that may decrease the emissions expected in the baseline scenario; these are, respectively: (i)
CH emissions from biomass burning and (ii) decrease in emissions expected in the baseline scenario, by 4
logging without the use of fire (durable goods). Was also calculated the significance of a possible emission
source that could lead to a reduction in avoided emissions under the PCFS scenario: (i) emissions from
deforestation in leakage management areas.
Below, an analysis of identified emissions sources.
Baseline Scenario
(I) CH4 from burning biomass
To determine the significance of CH4 emitted through the burning of biomass, we used the equation
presented in Step 6.2 of the Methodology VM0015 v1.0:
(10)
Whereby:
EBBCO2icl, t = CO2 emissions per hectare from burning of biomass per forest class in year t icl: *
CO2e ha-1
EBBCH4icl, t = CH4 emissions per hectare from burning of biomass per forest class in year t icl: *
CO2e ha-1
ERCH4 = Emission rate for CH4 (IPCC default value = 0.012).
GWPCH4 = Global Warming Potential for CH4 (IPCC default value = 21 for the first commitment
period).
The result of this equation gives the value of 52.53 tCO2e*ha-1. However, a combustion efficiency of 50% is
assumed (Step 6.2, VM0015 v1.0 ) such that CH4 emissions represent 4.6% of the emissions per hectare.
This source has been shown not significant and conservatively will not be counted as an avoided emission in
the PCFS.
(ii) Durable Wood Products
We calculated the significance level of potential logging that does not use fire (eg. for the production of
durable goods like furniture, etc.) and hence does not produce GHG emissions. To perform the calculations
we used the following assumptions:
ÔÇ∑ Net Emission Factor per hectare: 586.8 tCO2
ÔÇ∑ Logging intensity 30m3/ha141
ÔÇ∑ Coefficient of volumetric efficiency: 45%142
ÔÇ∑ Wood density = 0.59 t/m3 143
ÔÇ∑ Carbon density = 0.485 tC / t biomass144
ÔÇ∑ Conversion factor for CO e = 44/12145 2
141 Putz, 2008
142 CONAMA, 2009
143 Nogueira, 2008
144 Silva, 2007
145 IPCC, 2006
91

VCS Project Description Template
ÔÇ∑ Permanence factor of CO e by the use of wood in durable goods: 30m3/ha * 45% * 0.59 * 0.485 2
* 3.666 = 14.16 tCO2e/ha
ÔÇ∑ Calculation of the significance level: 14.16 tCO2 / 586.8 tCO2 = 0.024 (2.4%)
And, it is assumed that logging would occur at an average intensity of 30m3/ha, according to known
exploitation intensitiesin tropical forests. Of total production, wood represents 45% of the extracted volume.
By applying the values for wood density and the carbon content of the biomass, the amount of carbon
removed from the forest for the production of durable goods may be estimated.
It is important to point out that the logging intensity values used here are extremely conservative because in
a degraded forest as found in TISS, a logging intensity of 30m3/ha of commercial species is unlikely.
The result of the calculation of significance (2.4%) indicates that this activity will not be counted because it is
below the level of significance established by the Methodology VM0015 v1.0.
PCFS Scenario
(I) Leakage Management Areas
As previously mentioned, it is expected that with project implementation there will be an increase of carbon
stocks in areas under leakage management as reforestation and agroforestry activities will be encouraged
and promoted by the project proponents.
If a very pessimistic scenario is assumed, whereby carbon stocks in leakage management areas totaling
3,416 ha decreased by 50% (from 47 tCO2/ha to 23.5 tCO2/ha) through deforestation caused by the Paiter-
Suru√≠, the total emissions from this loss would represent 4.0% of expected emission reductions in the project
scenario (per hectare) and therefore is not considered significant and will not be counted as an potential
emission source in the project scenario.

1.8 A description of how the project will achieve GHG emission reductions
and/or removal enhancements:
The project activity under consideration entails electricity generation through wind-
mills by harnessing wind power potential, a natural and renewable source of energy.
The project is expected to generate and export 29.01 million kWh (approx) of power
per year to the Southern Regional Grid of India. In the absence of the project activity,
an equivalent quantity of electricity would have been generated by the Southern Grid
by a majority of fossil-fuel fired power plants. The same would have resulted in GHG
emissions as per the carbon intensity of the grid-mix.
As per the combined margin, carbon intensity of 0.927 tCO /MWh for the Southern 2
Grid has been used during calculation of emission reductions. The bundled project
activity would there by result in total CO emission reduction of 269, 050 tonnes over 2
the crediting period of 10 years. For detailed calculation procedure and sample
calculation tables of the GHG emission reduction, please refer to the Sections 4.2,

The estimates of emission reduction are provided to facilitate evaluation of emission reduction from the
Project. The total estimated emission reduction to be achieved by the project is about 82,553 tons of
CO2e over the crediting period.
With an average annual generation of approximately 92.101 GWh, the Project will reduce emissions by
56,427 tons of CO2e per year and hence the project activity is categorized as ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù.

Soil organic carbon
Estimations of soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks were done in accordance to the ‚ÄúTool for the estimation of
change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of A/R CDM project activity‚Äù. As suggested
by the tool, it is assumed that the implementation of the project activity increases the SOC content of the
lands from the pre-project level to the level that is equal to the steady-state SOC content under native
vegetation. The increase in SOC content in the project scenario takes place at a constant rate over a period
of 20 years from the year of planting. The project meets the applicability conditions of this tool since:
ÔÇ∑ the areas of land to which the tool is applied do not fall into wetland category, do not contain organic
soils and are not subject to any of the land management practices and application of inputs listed
in Tables 1 and 2 of the tool;
ÔÇ∑ Since the land use prior to project start is grassland, only Table 2 applies. For the temperate warm
moist climate region corresponding to the project activity, none of the three combinations included
in Table 2 are applicable;
ÔÇ∑ litter remains on site and is not removed and soil disturbance is in accordance with appropriate
conservation practices, limited to site preparation and not repeated within 20 years.
Table 13. Parameters used for estimation of SOC

In accordance with the selected CDM methodology, the greenhouse gas emissions of the proposed project
activities can be neglected (Section I, paragraph 3). However, in the framework of the VCS, relevant
greenhouse gas emissions of the baseline scenario shall be considered (VCS 2007.1, paragraph 6.3.1).
The baseline studies made by CIRAD (200040; 200141) first described the activities present in the
reference scenario and the project scenario (Table 9) within project boundary, and then listed all GHG
sources related to the activities approached (Table 10).
Table 9: Activities of reference scenario and project scenario.
Table 10: Carbon pools and GHG sources of reference scenario and project scenario.
Emissions from combustion of fossil fuel
The combustion of fossil fuels occurs in both reference and project scenario but the related GHG
emissions are supposed to be higher in the project scenario because of additional activities (reforestation
activities). However, they should be very low and negligible in comparison with CO removals from 2
forest plantations.
The GHG emissions were calculated by following IPCC GL 2006 with the date monitored in the fazenda.
Every year, 2‚Äô000 liters of diesel oil are consumed by project activities. Depending on years, a trade-off
exists between activities but global consumption remains similar. By applying IPCC method and default
values (EF = 2.707 kgCO .L-1), a total of 54.14 tCO were emitted during the last 10 years, since Diesel oil 2 2
project start. If this result is compared to the GHG emissions from fossil fuel combustion of the reference
scenario, the net GHG emissions can reasonably be neglected.
Emissions from biomass burning
40 Locatelli, B., 2000. Mesure de la fixation et crit√®res d‚Äô√©valuation d‚Äôun puits de carbone: application au projet ONF-Peugeot
(S√£o Nicolau, Mato Grosso, Br√©sil). Rapport de mission du 5 au 17 mars. CIRAD, Montpellier, 77 p.
41 Locatelli, B., 2001. Bilan carbone du projet ‚ÄúPuits de Carbone ¬ª ONF-Peugeot (Fazenda S√£o Nicolau, Mato

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM-SSC-AR-PDD) - Version 02
____________________________________________________________________________________
C DM ‚Äì Executive Board
Page 56
In the reference scenario, with the continuation of cattle grazing activities, annual fire is a common
practice for pasture management. Fire is used each year in order to stimulate growth of grasses. In terms
of greenhouse gas, CO , CH , CO, NO and N O are emitted. While CO emissions are compensated by 2 4 x 2 2
the regrowth of grasses, the other GHG emissions remain in the atmosphere, representing a GHG source.
In the project scenario such practice is not used as pastures are converted to forest lands. Thus, GHG
emissions from biomass burning in the reference scenario are net GHG emissions, but if accidental fires
occur in the project area. Therefore GHG emissions from biomass burning could represent a relevant
GHG source.
However, such emissions need large amount of biomass burning to be significant. As an example CH is 4
the main GHG released during biomass burning with an emission factor of 67 g.(kg d.m)-1, in comparison
with other GHG that have emissions factors lower than 4 g.(kg d.m)-1. Considering a hypothetical initial
biomass of 30 t d.m.ha-1 in pasture of the project area, which is high, the CH released during biomass 4
burning of the whole project area would be 16 tCO -e each year. Therefore, as GHG emissions from 2
fossil fuel combustion, GHG emissions from biomass burning can reasonably be neglected.
Emissions from enteric fermentation
This item represents the major GHG source inside project in the baseline scenario. As mentioned above,
3‚Äô960 heads of cattle pre-existed before project start and then were killed at project start. Thus, the
difference between GHG emissions from enteric fermentation in the reference scenario shall be
significant compared with project scenario.
However, in the project scenario, some animals of neighboring fazendas are present inside project area.
The neighboring animals are authorized inside project area for weed control and to generate additional
incomes from land renting. Thus, some cattle are still present inside project area with a low mean annual
presence of 822 heads since project start.
Therefore, even with animals still present inside project area, the difference of GHG emissions from
enteric fermentation between reference scenario and project scenario will be significant, as a
buffalo emits more than 1 tCO -e.year-1, and therefore will be estimated following IPCC GL 2006 in 2
accordance with VCS recommendations.
Emissions from the decomposition of dead wood
Dead wood is a main compartment in the reference scenario and the project scenario as natural forest was
slashed and burnt by the former landowner in order to open pastures for cattle grazing activities, and the
lying dead wood left on site.
In the reference scenario, dead wood is burnt year after year through pasture management by fire. The
remaining burnt dead wood participates to the process of decomposition. In the project scenario the dead
wood is neither displaced nor burnt. Therefore, it completely participates to the process of decomposition.
In consequence, it can reasonably be argued that GHG emissions from dead wood burning in the
reference scenario are almost equivalent to GHG emissions from dead wood decomposition in the project
scenario considering that CH is the main GHG involved in both processes. 4
Moreover, the inputs of dead wood from the management of forest plantations shall not lead to significant
additional GHG emissions considering the low amounts of GHG released during decomposition of dead

____________________________________________________________________________________
C DM ‚Äì Executive Board

wood, as during biomass burning. Therefore GHG emissions from the decomposition of dead wood
can reasonably be neglected.

Estimating carbon stock in trees at a point in time:
To estimate the carbon stock in tree biomass at a point in time. the following tool was used: ‚ÄúEstimation of
carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs in A/R CDM project activities AR-TOOL14
Version 04.1‚Äù. According to section 8.2 of this tool. this method is used for ex-ante estimation (projection)
of carbon stock in tree biomass. Under this method. existing data are used in combination with tree
growth models to predict the growth of trees and the development of the tree stand over time.
- Step 1: Tree carbon estimation
According to point 6 of Annex 1 of the AR-TOOL 14, for ex-ante estimation the allometric equation
applied to a tree species shall be selected from the following sources:
a) Existing data applicable to local situation (e.g. represented by similar ecological conditions).
b) National data (e.g. from national forest inventory or national greenhouse gas (GHG) inventory).
c) Data from neighbouring countries with similar conditions.
d) Globally applicable data.
An equation for H. Brasilensis derived from national inventories has not been developed for Colombia.
The equation available for this specie in the country depends on allometric parameters and there is not an

- Step 4: soil organic carbon
Estimations of soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks were done in accordance to the ‚ÄïTool for the estimation
of change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of A/R CDM project activity version
1.1.0‚Äñ (Annex 12). As suggested by the tool. it is assumed that the implementation of the project activity
increases the SOC content of the lands from the pre-project level to the level that is equal to the steady-
state SOC content under native vegetation. The increase in SOC content in the project scenario takes
place at a constant rate over a period of 20 years from the year of planting. The project meets the
applicability conditions of this tool in the area managed with rubber plantations:
The areas of land to which the tool is applied do not fall into wetland category, do not contain organic
soils and are not subject to any of the land management practices and application of inputs listed in
Tables 1 and 2 of the tool.
Since the land use prior to project start was grassland, only Table 2 applies. For the Tropical, moist
climate region corresponding to the project activity, none of the three combinations included in Table 15
are applicable; litter remains on site and is not removed and soil disturbance is in accordance with
appropriate conservation practices, limited to site preparation and less than 10%. As the main goal of the
project is not the wood harvesting, but the rubber. Not additional site preparations will be developed at
least for the first 35 years of the rubber productivity cycle (less than 20 years).

Wind power is one of the cleanest sources of renewable energy, with no
associated emissions and waste products. As per the Schedule 1 of Ministry
of Environment and Forests (Government of India) notification9 dated
September 14, 2006, wind power projects do not require an Environmental
Impact Assessment. However, certain foreseen impacts due to the project
activity are discussed below:
Noise Pollution
Most of the wind turbines are in isolated areas or on designated wind zones
and hence do not cause any concern to the residents of the area. In the same
vein, construction activities also have not caused noise pollution due to the
isolated nature of the area.
Water Pollution
There is no gaseous, liquid or solid effluent from the Wind Turbine
Generators. Hence there is no contamination of water bodies due to
operation of Wind Turbine Generators.
Air Pollution
Minimal air pollution might have occurred during the construction of the
Project due to transportation. However, these were not found to affect the
surrounding persons nor the environment in any significant manner. Wind

energy plants are known to contribute to zero atmospheric pollution as no
fuel combustion is involved during any stage of the operation.
Hence it can be concluded that there are no negative impacts associated
with the mentioned Project.
5 Environmental Impact:
The project activity is a clean energy project using renewable source of
energy, wind, to generate power. It has already received permission from
Maharashtra Energy Development Agency (MEDA) which is a department
of the State Government of Maharashtra.
The project activity is exempted from carrying out any EIA as per the
notification S.O.1533 dated 14/09/2006 of Ministry of Environment and
Forests, Government of India.
6 Stakeholders comments:
A stakeholder consultation meeting was organized for this project activity.
The copy of the public notice inviting stakeholders to the meeting, copy of
the attendance sheet and copy of Minutes of Stakeholder Consultation are
attached in Annexure 3.
There were no specific negative comments. The apprehensions of the
stakeholders were cleared to satisfaction. Since there were no negative
comments, there were no changes to the Project.
Maharashtra Energy Development Agency (State Government of
Maharashtra Undertaking) has also given their infrastructure clearance for
setting up the project activity.

3.4 Summary of GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
The total net of GHG reductions of the REDD Project are calculated as follows:
C = ‚àÜC - ‚àÜC - ‚àÜC REDD,t BSL P LK
Where,
C = Total GHG emission reduction REDD,t
‚àÜC = Net emissions under baseline BSL
‚àÜC = Net emissions under project scenario P
‚àÜC = Net emissions by leakage LK
As shown in the calculations developed, there is no variation in carbon stocks by deforestation in
the with-project case (ex-ante), as the Madre de Dios Amazon REDD Project will carry out
activities to avoid the projected deforestation in 100%. On the other hand, there is no sufficiently
reliable estimation about the increase in biomass by the actions of enrichment in the Project Area.
v3.0 1 61

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Therefore, based on the monitoring to be carried out calculations ex post will be made for this
item.
The emissions due to leakage inside and outside the Leakage Belt that have been calculated
following Module LK-ASU amount to 816,783.62 tCO for the first 10 years. The percentages and 2
indexes found in the different steps of the estimation are based in the analysis of the official
information on the population, as the National Census of 2007 and current studies of the area
carried out by NGO‚Äôs and different researchers.
Therefore, the Total Reduction of GHGs Emissions in the Project Area would be equal to
10,603,153 tCO2 (11.419.937 - 816,783.62 tCO2) for the first ten years and 25,072,135 tCO2 for
the entire life of the project. However, the project should be monitored to verify stock changes by
deforestation (unlikely to occur) and if the leakage established (ex-ante) is in fact attributable to
the project or the amount has been overestimated and increase the carbon stock in a project
scenario by enrichment in the project area.
Estimation on the VCS buffer
The Buffer retention is estimated as a percentage of the subtraction between the Total Emissions
by Unplanned Deforestation in Baseline and the Emissions in the Scenario with Project,
regardless of the discounts by leakage. Previously, each one has to subtract their emissions by
burning of fossil fuels and the incorporation of nitrogen.
The retention rate is determined according to the risk classification of the project, using the VCS
tool for AFOLU of Risk of Non Permanence. According to the calculations, it has a total
percentage of 10% buffer.
Therefore the retention of Buffer Credits to year 2018 should be:
Buffer = {(11,419,937 ‚Äì 0*) ‚Äì 0**} x 10% = 1,141,994 tCO UNPLANNED 2
And to 2046 (end of the accreditation period):
Buffer = {(27,626,600 ‚Äì 0*) ‚Äì 0**} x 10% = 2,762,660 tCO UNPLANNED 2
* It was already explained that the emissions due to the burning of fossil fuels and the
incorporation of nitrogen fertilizers in baseline were not considered.
** There are no changes in carbon stocks in Scenario with Project (ex - ante) due to the planned
prevention activities, and because none of them have considered using fertilizers.
Uncertainty Analysis
The analysis of uncertainty of carbon stocks was developed according to the module X-UNC.
The assumptions made were:

Fossil fuel combustion and N O emissions from nitrogen application, were not analysed as 2

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
conditions under which methane emissions are measured for projects under this
methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by expert
from Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences under the jurisdiction of the Anhui Agricultural
Bureau. Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences is a comprehensive agricultural research
institution directly under the provincial government. The expert who is the leader of the
experiment has a doctoral degree and her field of study is rice cultivation and GHG
monitoring33 . The chamber measurements were conducted by technicians trained by the
expert on 07 March 2017 for the early season and 10 July 2017 for the second season,
respectively34. The base is embedded just before transplanting, and the first gas sampling
began on the second day after transplanting, followed by sampling every 7 days. After
sampling, the gas is stored in the evacuated vial, and the samples collected after three times
should be taken together for laboratory analysis.
2. Project proponents shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane
measurements before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule for the
field and laboratory measurements, the logistics that are necessary to get the gas
samples to the laboratory and a cropping calendar. The plan shall also include all
reference field specific information regarding location and climate, soil, water
management, plant characteristics, fertilizer treatment and organic amendments.
The details of the reference fields for measuring EF and the plan for the seasonal BL,c
methane measurements before the start of the season is shown as following:

The ex ante projections assume that no deforestation, or other sources of emissions, occurs in the project
in the with-project case, i.e. that park protection activities are successful in preventing land clearing within
the park boundary. Park protection and border patrolling, as well as community awareness programs, are
key components to the project implementation. CIMA has a proven track record from 2003 to 2008, of
effective protection work and conflict resolution.
There are no standard approaches to estimate future leakage attributable to a REDD activity, nor does
the methodology provide detailed guidance. Some leakage due to the project is expected. However, as
detailed in the project description, project implementation focuses on activities that should reduce
leakage, including support to potential leakage agents (i.e. communities in the park buffer zone) in
increasing crop productivity, land zoning and securing land tenure. To be conservative, a 20% annual
leakage rate is used.

According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU
Methodology, the following requirements should be met.
1. The implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the
involvement of experts in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts
(i.e. from research institutions). These guidelines cannot replace expertise in
setting up chamber measurements. They rather set minimum requirements that
serve for standardizing the conditions under which methane emissions are
measured for projects under this methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by
experts from Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences under the jurisdiction of the Anhui
Agricultural Bureau. Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences is a comprehensive
agricultural research institution directly under the provincial government. The expert who is
the leader of the experiment has a doctoral degree and her field of study is agricultural
environmental engineering33. The expert set up the chamber measurements on 7 March
2017 for the early season and 9 July 2017 for the second season, respectively34. The base
is embedded just before transplanting, and the first gas sampling began on the second day
after transplanting, followed by sampling every 7days. After sampling, the gas is stored in
the evacuated vial, and the samples collected after three times should be taken together for
laboratory analysis.
2. Project proponents shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane
measurements before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule
for the field and laboratory measurements, the logistics that are necessary to get

4.2 Quantifying GHG emissions and/or removals for the
baseline scenario:
Baseline emissions are calculated with combined baseline emission factor and the net
electricity delivered to the grid by the project.
According to the FSR of the project, the average annual net Electricity Export is
estimated to be 211,080 MW h while the actual measured Electricity Export in 2006,
2007 and 2008 were 149,514, 219,545, 187,980 MWh. Hence the actual annual and
estimated baseline emission of the project in the first crediting period are calculated as
below.
From Apr. 1, 2006 to Dec.31, 2006
BE = EG √ó EF = 149,514 √ó 0.8712 √ó 275/365 = 98,139 t CO e y y y 2

crediting period. It should be measured by using closed chamber in three reference fields
which are chosen in the project area.
According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU
Methodology, the following requirements should be met.
1. The implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the
involvement of experts in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts
(i.e. from research institutions). These guidelines cannot replace expertise in
setting up chamber measurements. They rather set minimum requirements that
serve for standardizing the conditions under which methane emissions are
measured for projects under this methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by
experts from Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences under the jurisdiction of the Anhui
Agricultural Bureau. Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences is a comprehensive
agricultural research institution directly under the provincial government. The expert who is
the leader of the experiment has a doctoral degree and her field of study is rice cultivation
and GHG monitoring32. The base was buried in the rice field by technicians trained by
expert on 8 March 2017 for the early season and 9 July 2017 for the second season,
respectively33. The base is embedded just before transplanting, and the first gas sampling
began on the second day after transplanting, followed by sampling every 7 days. After
sampling, the gas is stored in the evacuated vial, and the samples collected after three
times should be taken together for laboratory analysis.
31 For all scaling factor used in this methodology, the average values in 2006 IPCC Guidelines for
National Greenhouse Gas Inventories are chosen.
32 Which can be proven by the CV of the expert
33 The Report of Measuring Methane Emission Rate of Paddy Fields with Continuously Flooded
Method by Closed Chamber in Chizhou City for early season was completed in August 2017, while
that for second season was completed in December 2017

4.3 Natural Capital and Ecosystem Services Monitoring Plan
Biodiversity Monitoring Plan (B4.1, B4.2, GL1.4, GL3.4)
Indicators are important in impact assessment because they respond to the basic question ‚Äúwhat
should be measured to show that the claimed net social benefits are real and additional?‚Äù (Richards &
Panfil 2011) An ideal indicator from the perspective of showing attribution is one that measures an
‚Äòintermediate state‚Äô or assumption between an output and outcome or an outcome and an impact,
clearly showing progress along a causal chain (Richards & Panfil, 2011). Thus, we used our theory of
change logic in the Result Chain diagrams (section Error! Reference source not found.) as the basis
for selecting indicators that factor in attribution. We then decided on the best sampling methods to use
to collect these data to acceptable levels accuracy, precision and cost effectiveness whilst retaining
transparency and simplicity. From this, a Monitoring Plan was developed to guide data collection.
Further, the indicators will be analyzed based on the Pressure-State-Response framework, which also
relies on a causal-chain logic, where threats negatively impact the status/condition of biodiversity, while
87

Project Description: SD VISta Version 1
responses or project interventions reduce pressure. Most Response indicators can be grouped under:
Habitat improvement; Security enhancement; and Improvement of community livelihoods efforts.
Pressure indicators fall under: Human population size and dynamics; Human-wildlife conflict (HWC);
and Incidences including poaching, grazing, encroachment, charcoal and firewood collection amongst
others. Finally, State indicators are grouped into three categories: wildlife (including species presence,
diversity, distribution and movement); vegetation and land-use (including changes in various
vegetation/habitat types, encroachment and fire). Most of the response and pressure indicators
correspond to the social indicators developed in the community monitoring plan (See Section. 4.3.1),
and so data collection follows the protocols outlined therein. On top, we determined 12 indicators not
part of the social indicator set, also classified into three categories: Output 4; Outcome 4; and Impact.
For these new indicators, two main strategies will be used to obtain the data: In-house reporting and
Government records, mostly for output and outcome indicators, and surveys for most impact indicators.
We envision three main aspects of state indicators to measure, each with a distinct set of monitoring
protocols:
Wildlife: wildlife surveys and monitoring for all species ‚Äì with a focus on HCVs ‚Äì will be done using
several methods: ranger patrols, camera traps, fecal-DNA analysis, and information from any
independent research projects in the area
Vegetation and Land-use: carbon plot monitoring plots and remote sensing (based on LANDSAT
imagery) and GIS techniques.
88

5.4 Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
The net change in carbon stocks during the monitoring period was -48,837 tCO2e. The net
GhG emissions reductions can be found at the bottom of the "PA Summary" worksheet. It
reflects the emission reductions calculated from the "Ex-Post Strata" worksheet, less the
Pending and Removed PAs.
Two non-permanence risk reports were prepared under Section 2.1.3 of the AFOLU Non-
Permanence Risk Tool, v4.0. Due to the harvesting reported in this PD and the Loss
Report, 12 PAs were evaluated separately from the remainder. That risk report, Non-
Permanence Risk Sub-Report KE001-L, failed. But for the reversal in KE001-L, there
would have been an increase of 19,505 tonnes in the remainder of the PD and the risk
report for the remaining PAs had a risk of 1.0. However, since there was a reversal, KE
VCS-001 is not eligible for any credits. The non-permanence risk reports are Appendix 12.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
According to the applied methodology AMS-‚Ö¢.AU (version 4.0), for the ex ante estimation
of emission reductions within the project design document prior to the project implementation,
project proponent shall refer to own field experiments or estimate baseline and project
emissions with the help of national data or IPCC tier 1 default values for emission and scaling
factors.
In this project, using the IPCC tier 1 approach but undertaking measurements to determine
baseline emission factors for continuously flooded fields, as per the following formula:

period. It should be measured by using closed chamber in three reference fields which are
chosen in the project area.
According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU
Methodology, the following requirements should be met.
1. The implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the involvement
of experts in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts (i.e. from
research institutions). These guidelines cannot replace expertise in setting up
chamber measurements. They rather set minimum requirements that serve for
standardizing the conditions under which methane emissions are measured for
projects under this methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by experts
from Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences under the jurisdiction of the Anhui Agricultural
Bureau. Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences is a comprehensive agricultural research
institution directly under the provincial government. The expert who is the leader of the
experiment has a doctoral degree and her field of study is rice cultivation and GHG
monitoring36. The on-field gas samplings were conducted by technicians trained by expert,
which were started by using the closed chamber on 5 March 2017 for the early season and
10 July 2017 for the second season, respectively37 . The base is embedded just before
transplanting, and the first gas sampling began on the second day after transplanting,
followed by sampling every 7days. After sampling, the gas is stored in the evacuated vial,
and the samples collected after three times should be taken together for laboratory analysis.
2. Project proponents shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane
measurements before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule

while that for second season was completed in November 2017

For calculation of the baseline emission factor, the six steps below should be followed as described
above:
STEP 1. Identify the relevant electricity system.
Considering the stated by the ‚ÄúTool to calculate the emission factor for an electricity system‚Äù, and the
fact that the Brazilian DNA has published the Resolution no 8 issued on May 26th, 2008, which defines
Brazilian Interconnected Grid as a single system that covers all five macro-geographical regions of the
51

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
country (North, Northeast, South, Southeast and Midwest), the Brazilian electricity system boundaries
are clearly defined.
STEP 2. Choose whether to include off-grid power plants in the project electricity system (optional).
Since the Brazilian DNA has made available the emission factor calculation based on information of the
grid power plants only, the off-grid power plants are not considered.
STEP 3. Select a method to determine the operating margin (OM).
The method adopted to calculate the operating margin is ‚ÄúDispatch data analysis OM‚Äù. The calculation
is performed by the Brazilian DNA and made publicly available.
The Dispatch Data emission factor (OM), is summarized as follows:

3.3 Leakage
In accordance with the applicability conditions of the required tool: ‚ÄúEstimation of the increase in
GHG emissions attributable to displacement of pre-project agricultural activities in A/R CDM
project activity‚Äù, SNP Patagonia Sur utilized the ‚ÄúGuidelines on conditions under which increase
in GHG emissions related to displacement of pre-project grazing activities in A/R CDM project
activity is insignificant‚Äù to demonstrate that leakage in the initial project activity instance is
insignificant. For evidence of the use of this tool and its guidance, please see supporting
document titled ‚ÄúSec 1.13 Leakage Statement‚Äù.
Due to this assessment of insignificance, Equation (7) of the Baseline Methodology Procedure
was not used to calculate leakage (See supporting document titled ‚ÄúSec 3 Baseline Procedure
Document‚Äù).
3.4 Summary of GHG Emission Reductions and Removals

the Project Description, refer to supporting document, ‚ÄúSec 3 Baseline Procedure Document‚Äù).

the baseline net GHG removals by sinks minus leakage, therefore, the following general formula

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
According to the applied methodology AMS-‚Ö¢.AU (version 4.0), for the ex ante estimation
of emission reductions within the project design document prior to the project implementation,
project proponent shall refer to own field experiments or estimate baseline and project
emissions with the help of national data or IPCC tier 1 default values for emission and scaling
factors.

Determination of EFBL,c
However, the baseline emission factor for continuously flooded fields without organic
amendments ( ) can be determined ex ante prior to the start of the project activity, in this
case, the ex ante value should be used to calculate emission reduction during the crediting ùêµùêµùê∏ùê∏ùêµùêµùêµùêµ,ùëêùëê
period. It should be measured by using closed chamber in three reference fields which are
chosen in the project area.
According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU
Methodology, the following requirements should be met.
1. The implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the involvement of
experts in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts (i.e. from research
institutions). These guidelines cannot replace expertise in setting up chamber measurements.
They rather set minimum requirements that serve for standardizing the conditions under
which methane emissions are measured for projects under this methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by experts
from Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences under the jurisdiction of the Anhui Agricultural
Bureau. Anhui Academy of Agricultural Sciences is a comprehensive agricultural research
institution directly under the provincial government. The expert who is the leader of the
experiment has a doctoral degree and her field of study is rice cultivation and GHG
monitoring34. The chamber measurements were conducted by technicians trained by expert
on 5 March 2017 for the early season and 10 July 2017 for the second season, respectively35.
The base is embedded just before transplanting, and the first gas sampling began on the
second day after transplanting, followed by sampling every 7days. After sampling, the gas is
stored in the evacuated vial, and the samples collected after three times should be taken
together for laboratory analysis.
2.Project proponents shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane measurements
before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule for the field and laboratory
measurements, the logistics that are necessary to get the gas samples to the laboratory and
a cropping calendar. The plan shall also include all reference field specific information
regarding location and climate, soil, water management, plant characteristics, fertilizer
treatment and organic amendments.

while that for second season was completed in November 2017.

(LEy) as follows:
Emission Reductions = ER - LE y y

This revision was due to the following aspects:
- Application of more accurate values for organic content and amount of Municipal Solid Waste (MSW)
historically disposed at the AMC landfill;
- Use of more appropriate approach for estimating the amount of methane to be generated at the AMC
landfill and to be collected by the project activity. Such estimations are performed by applying a more recent
and appropriated approach as per the methodological tool ‚ÄúEmission from solid waste disposal sites‚Äù
(version 6.0.1).
- Consideration of leakage emissions due to the consumption of both grid-sourced electricity and LPG by
the project activity
- Consideration of the correct value for the ex-ante determined parameter CF (density of methane).

Soil organic carbon
Estimations of soil organic carbon (SOC) stocks were done in accordance to the ‚ÄúTool for the estimation of
change in soil organic carbon stocks due to the implementation of A/R CDM project activity‚Äù. As suggested
by the tool, it is assumed that the implementation of the project activity increases the SOC content of the
lands from the pre-project level to the level that is equal to the steady-state SOC content under native
vegetation. The increase in SOC content in the project scenario takes place at a constant rate over a period
of 20 years from the year of planting. The project meets the applicability conditions of this tool in the area
managed with Pine plantations:
‚Ä¢ the areas of land to which the tool is applied do not fall into wetland category, do not contain
organic soils and are not subject to any of the land management practices and application of
inputs listed in Tables 1 and 2 of the tool;
‚Ä¢ Since the land use prior to project start was grassland, only Table 2 applies. For the
temperate warm moist climate region corresponding to the project activity, none of the three
combinations included in Table 2 are applicable;
‚Ä¢ litter remains on site and is not removed and soil disturbance is in accordance with
appropriate conservation practices, limited to site preparation and not repeated within 20
years.
Table 19. Parameters used for estimation of SOC

reference SOC. As per the tool, a loss in SOC (SOC ) is applied in the case that soil disturbance LOSS,i
occurs on more than 10 per cent of the land area, which is the case of Weyerhaeuser Uruguay project.

5 Environmental Impact:
As described in section 1.7 of this Project Description, the land on which the Red
Hills Wind Farm is being constructed is rural agricultural farmland, which is best
suited for pasturing livestock and the cultivation of wheat and cotton crops.
Local development consists primarily of widely dispersed individual farmsteads.
Socioeconomic and environmental activity in the project area will remain
unchanged upon completion of the wind farm construction and operation. No
dislocation of people or wildlife will occur as a result of the project activity.
There are no federal authorizations or permits required for the project that would
entail consultation under Section 7 of the Endangered Species Act, to include the
need to obtain project authorization from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. There
are four federally listed endangered or threatened species that potentially occur in
the general vicinity of the Red Hills Wind Project: the interior least tern, whooping
crane, piping plover, and the Arkansas River shiner. The project activity has been
designed to avoid impacts on the United States waterways.
Acciona Wind Energy USA LLC voluntarily contracted HDR Engineering, Inc.
(HDR) and Western Ecosystems Technology Inc. to complete the environmental
site assessment (ESA) and Biological Assessment of the property proposed for the
Red Hills Wind Project. The environmental assessment was completed by HDR on
January 30, 2008 and the biological assessment was completed by Western
Ecosystems on March 27, 2008.
Western Ecosystems determined that; ‚ÄúThe Red Hills project avoids many of the
potential impacts to whooping cranes due to its distal proximity to the main
migratory flyway.‚Äù Western Ecosystems also determined that other aforementioned
endangered species were not threatened by the project activity.
Acciona voluntarily contracted Western Ecosystems to conduct a voluntary bat
assessment using acoustic monitoring equipment. Additionally post construction
bat mortality monitoring will take place for one year after operation of the facility
begins. Any bats that are found during these mortality studies will be offered as a
donation to the American Museum of Natural History for their ongoing Genomic
Studies.
Further studies such as the wetlands delineation was conducted on November 26
and 27, 2007, by two HDR biologists. The survey was conducted in accordance
with the Corps of Engineers Wetlands Delineation Manual (Environmental
Laboratory, 1987).
Acciona proposes to implement the following design, siting, and conservation
measures to ensure to that the ecological environment is not affected by the project
activity:
‚Ä¢ Turbine Design: Acciona will use monopole, tubular designs that
eliminate avian perching sites. Guy wires will not be used on
turbines. If guy wires are used on the permanent and temporary
meteorological towers within the project, appropriate high visibility
markings will be used.
‚Ä¢ Collector Line Design: Acciona will bury the majority (about 88%) of
the collector lines for the project. For the overhead collector line
41

Proprietary and Confidential
segments and the overhead 138 kV transmission line, Acciona will
mark the lines in accordance with methods recommended by the
Avian Power Line Committee (APLIC).
‚Ä¢ Transmission Line: Using guidance from APLIC‚Äôs Suggested
Practices for Avian Protection on Power Lines, approximately 4 miles
of on-site overhead 138 kV transmission line will be designed to
minimize the potential for bird electrocutions.
‚Ä¢ Lighting: The Red Hills Wind Project will use the minimum amount
of lighting as required by Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
Lighting is anticipated to be pulsating red light on the minimum
number of turbines as required by the FAA in order to reduce the
disturbances on the local population.
‚Ä¢ Air Impacts: Wind Power plants do not contribute to atmospheric
pollution as no fuel combustion is involved during any stage of the
operation. The primary emissions source for the project will be motor
vehicle exhaust resulting from construction and maintenance of the
project. However, in light of the project activity and the resulting
emission reductions, motor vehicle emissions will be a very minor
emissions source.
‚Ä¢ Noise Impacts: Personal protective equipment is provided to workers
involved in construction activity to mitigate the effects of noise
pollution. Taking into consideration the project life cycle, the
magnitude of the impacts during the construction phase are negligible
and exists for a temporary period of time until the end of construction
phase. Therefore, noise pollution will also be a very minor issue and
will not harm the environment.
Acciona recognizes the concerns over the relationship between wind energy
development and the ecological environment of the project activity. As such,
commitments have been made to evaluate and immediately address issues that
impact the project activity area.
42

Proprietary and Confidential
6 Stakeholders‚Äô comments:
Stakeholders for the Red Hills Wind Farm project include landowners, local
residents, local officials, and Acciona staff.
Roger Mills County held public meetings on February 11th and June 16th 2008 to
discuss permitting issues for the Red Hills Wind Farm. During these meetings,
local constituents were provided the opportunity and platform to discuss their
concerns about the project activity.
Each meeting began with a brief progress update for the project activity by the
project developer, construction manager, and other project officials. The overall
reaction can be summarized as positive. The local residents expressed satisfaction
that the project activity has created local employment which is improving the
standard of life as well as socio-economic conditions of the surrounding area.
Moreover, local landowners have expressed satisfaction that the project activity has
led to an increase in land values.
Only one negative issue was raised by one non-participating landowner at the
February 11th meeting. This landowner raised concerns that the turbines were too
close to the fence surrounding his property, which is not in the project activity
area. This concern was investigated by the project developer and it was discovered
that the landowner had mistaken a property survey stake that was about 30 feet
from his fence for a turbine-staked location. This issue was resolved through
further communication with the landowner and was publicly addressed at the June
16th community meeting.
In July 2008, two non-participating landowners from Roger Mills County requested
to meet with the project developer to express concerns that the project activity was
located too close to their property lines. The landowners expressed that they felt
that permitting had occurred without their knowledge and felt that they had been
circumvented in the process. Over the course of a two-hour meeting, it was pointed
out that Acciona had followed the counties permitting guidance and that there were
two public meetings that they did not attend.
These landowners as well as all stakeholders involved in this project activity will be
notified of all future public meetings.
43

Proprietary and Confidential
7 Schedule:
The Red Hills crediting period will begin on the commercial operation date of
October 26, 2008 and will last for 10 years thereafter. The lifespan of the wind
farm is expected to be 20 years after the operational date. The project activity will
not be terminated for any reason, other than for emergencies, until the end of the
operational life. Validation will be complete upon review and approval of this
document. Verification will occur depending on the needs of project participants.
44

Proprietary and Confidential

The number of credits to be held in the permanence risk buffer (as per the VCS) is determined as a
percentage of the total carbon stock benefits. This is equal to the net emissions in the baseline minus
emissions from fossil fuel use and fertilizer use minus the net emissions in the project case minus
emissions from fossil fuels and fertilizer use. Leakage emissions do not factor into the buffer calculations.

According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU
Methodology, the following requirements should be met.
1. The implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the
involvement of experts in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts
(i.e. from research institutions). These guidelines cannot replace expertise in
setting up chamber measurements. They rather set minimum requirements that
serve for standardizing the conditions under which methane emissions are
measured for projects under this methodology.
The closed chamber measurement requires the involvement of technicians trained by
experts from China National Rice Research Institute and the technical team from Search
Co2. China National Rice Research Institute (CRRI) is a national multi-disciplinary research
institute with rice as its main research object. The base is embedded just before
transplanting, and the first gas sampling began on the second day after transplanting,
followed by sampling every 7 days. After sampling, the gas is stored in the evacuated vial,
and the samples collected after three times should be taken together for laboratory
analysis.
34 For all scaling factor used in this methodology, the average values in 2006 IPCC Guidelines for
National Greenhouse Gas Inventories are chosen.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
3 QUANTIFICATION OF GHG EMISSION REDUCTIONS AND REMOVALS
3.1 Baseline Emissions
Baseline emissions are calculated as the carbon pools measured in the project area, which are
applied to the deforestation model. The amounts of emissions assigned for each selected carbon
pool depicted in the table in Section 2.3 are determined at the verification stage. It should be
noted that it is not mandatory to measure ex-ante carbon stocks in the project area according to
the applied methodology. The ex-ante estimates of the net carbon benefits of the project are only
required to determine whether decreases in carbon pools or increases in GHG emissions are
insignificant and need not be measured and monitored.
Table 16: Estimated baseline emissions for selected carbon pools over total project crediting period.
A spreadsheet with the complete GHG emission analysis for the entire project crediting period is
provided separately to the auditor68.
The sum of estimated emissions over selected carbon pools is calculated according to eq. 20 of
the methodology.
The following equations from the methodology will be used at the monitoring and verification
stage to calculate the baseline emissions:
‚Ä¢ Baseline emissions in above ground large trees is calculated using eq. 21.
‚Ä¢ Baseline emissions for above ground small trees is calculated using eq. 22.
‚Ä¢ Baseline emissions in above ground non tree biomass is calculated using eq. 23.
‚Ä¢ Baseline emissions in below ground large trees is calculated using eq. 24.
‚Ä¢ Baseline emissions for below ground small trees is calculated using eq. 25.
‚Ä¢ Baseline emissions in below ground non tree biomass is calculated using eq. 26.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
3.2 Project Emissions
Project emissions for any monitoring period are estimated by the events of woody biomass
consumption.
Forest fires: The Project proponent understands that should significant forest fires occur during
the project crediting period, a map of the boundaries of the fire during the monitoring period will
be elaborated. The project area may need to be re-stratified based on the significance of fire
events.
Emissions from burning: No emissions from the burning of woody biomass as a result of project
activities in the project area occur.
The project emissions are calculated according to equation 31 of the methodology.

As described in section 4.1, the quantification of the baseline scenario was done according
to version 20 of the ACM0002 methodology where only CO emissions from electricity 2
generation from fossil fuel fired power plants that are displaced due to the project activity
are included. The ex-ante baseline emissions were, therefore, calculated according to
Equation 1, described in section 4.1.
Operating Margin
The Operating Margin (OM) was calculated according to the ‚ÄúTool to calculate the emission
factor for an electricity system.‚Äù The specific method chosen was the Simple OM Option A.
The OM is calculated ex ante using a three-year generation-weighted average, based on
the most recent data available at the time of PD submission. Based on the EIA data, this is
the years of 2019, 2018, and 2016, where the OM emission factor is calculated for each
year then averaged. Per application of Option A for computing the simple OM, the OM
calculation correctly included the LCMR<50% analysis to confirm the applicability of Option
A. No off-grid power plants were used in the computations. The OM was calculated as
follows:

3.4 Estimated Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
Emission reduction (ER ): y
The project activity mainly reduces carbon dioxide through substitution of grid electricity
generation with fossil fuel fired power plant by renewable electricity. The emission reduction ER y
by the project activity during a given year y is the difference between Baseline emission and
Project emission & Leakage emission. The emission reduction is calculated in line with para 58 of
AC0002, Version 17, using equation below:
ER = BE -PE - LE y y y y
Where,
ER = Emission Reduction in tCO /year y 2
BE = Baseline emission in tCO /year y 2
PE = Project emissions in tCO /year y 2
LE = Leakage Emissions in tCO /year y 2

3.4.1 Calculation of ex-ante estimation of total net GHG emissions reductions and VCUs
Net GHG emissions reductions
According to section 9.2 of the methodology, net anthropogenic GHG emission reduction of the proposed
AUD project activity is calculated as follows:
ŒîREDD = (ŒîCBSLPA + EBBBSLPA) ‚Äì (ŒîCPSPA + EBBPSPA) ‚Äì (ŒîCLK + ELK) t t t t t t t
Where:
ŒîREDD = Ex-ante estimated net anthropogenic greenhouse gas emission reduction attributable to the AUD t
project activity at year t; tCO e 2
ŒîCBSLPA = Sum of baseline carbon stock changes in the project area at year t; tCO e t 2
EBBBSLPA = Sum of baseline emissions from biomass burning in the project area at year t; tCO e t 2
ŒîCPSPA= Sum of ex-ante estimated actual carbon stock changes in the project area at year t; tCO e t 2
EBBPSPA= Sum of (ex-ante estimated) actual emissions from biomass burning in the project area at year t
t; tCO e 2
ŒîCLKt= Sum of ex-ante estimated leakage net carbon stock changes at year t; tCO e 2
ELK= Sum of ex-ante estimated leakage emissions at year t; tCO e t 2
t 1, 2, 3 ‚Ä¶ T, a year of the proposed project crediting period; dimensionless
As mentioned in sections 2.6 Methodology Deviations and 3.2 Project Emissions, the project does not
consider leakage emissions nor non-CO emissions, so the equation is reduced to: 2
ŒîREDD = ŒîCBSLPA‚Äì ŒîCPSPA t t t

Ex-ante calculation of emission reductions:
Simple Operating margin (OM)
As also explained above, for the computation of the Simple OM, the Ex-Ante option is selected, at the
time of PDD submission to the DOE, the data vintages that were most recent, belongs to the years
2008, 2009 and 2010. All the data used in calculation of the Simple OM are taken from the TEƒ∞A≈û
website, details of which are given below. Taking into account the available data ‚ÄúSimple OM‚Äù method
‚ÄúOption B‚Äù is the appropriate method for the project activity. TEƒ∞A≈û publishes the annual heating
values of the fuels consumed in the power plants, the heating values are directly related to fuel
consumption and are used to calculate average Net Calorific Values (TJ/kt) (Table 10).
The heating values of fuels consumed in thermal power plants are announced by TEƒ∞A≈û, the unit of
the heating values are Tcal. Tcal is converted to GJoule by using the conversion factor 1cal = 4.1868
Joule. Then the heating values in GJ are divided by Fuel Consumption (FC ) to get the Net Calorific i,y
Values of the fuels consumed in TJ/kt as follows:
