Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Table 16: Stratification based on Project activities.
Estimating carbon stock in trees at a point of time
To estimate the carbon stock in tree biomass at a point of time, the following tool was used:
‚ÄúEstimation of carbon stocks and change in carbon stocks of trees and shrubs in A/R CDM
project activities‚Äù, AR-TOOL14 (Version 04.1). According to Section 8.2 of this tool, this
method is used for ex-ante estimation (projection) of carbon stock in tree biomass.
Step 1: Tree biomass estimation
An equation for Eucalyptus uro-grandis derived from age has not been found. The equa-
tions available for this species depend on allometric parameters and there is not an avail-
able database with allometric parameters that allow us to adjust a time equation to estimate
the ex-ante carbon stocks.
Considering this, the annual increment in volume of wood suitable for industrial processing
value (I V) of 36.25 m¬≥ha-1year-1 (trunk biomass volume) was used in combination with other
parameters derived from ANNEX 3A.1 ‚ÄúBiomass Default Tables for Section 3.2 Forest
Land‚Äù of IPCC Good Practice Guidance for LULUCF, to find the total biomass per hectare
(Table 17).
Table 17: Parameters used to estimate the total biomass (below+above) per hectare per year.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
Determination of EF BL, c
However, the baseline emission factor for continuously flooded fields without organic
amendments (EF ) can be determined ex-ante prior to the start of the project activity, in this BL, c
case, the ex-ante value should be used to calculate emission reduction during the crediting
period. It should be measured by using Closed Chamber in three reference fields which are
chosen in the project area.
According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU Methodology,
the implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the involvement of experts
in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts (i.e., from research institutions). These
guidelines cannot replace expertise in setting up chamber measurements. They rather set
minimum requirements that serve for standardizing the conditions under which methane
emissions are measured for projects under this methodology.
1) The Closed Chamber measurement requires the cooperation of the experts from Huazhong
Agricultural University and the staff of the Agricultural Bureau of Qianxi City and Agricultural
Bureau of Jinsha County. Huazhong Agricultural University is an institution of higher learning
of agriculture in China. The experts set up the chamber measurements on 10-April-2017. The
base is embedded just before transplanting, and the first gas sampling began on the second
day after transplanting, followed by sampling every 7 days. After sampling, as is stored in the
evacuated vial, and the samples collected after three times should be taken together for
laboratory analysis.
2) Project proponent shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane measurements
before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule for the field and laboratory
measurements, the logistics that are necessary to get the gas samples to the laboratory and
a cropping calendar. The plan shall also include all reference field specific information
14 For all scaling factor used in this methodology, the average values in 2006 IPCC Guidelines for
National Greenhouse Gas Inventories are chosen.

4.4 Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
Uncertainty Factor Calculation
VM0012 utilized an Uncertainty Factor calculation to account for additional ‚Äòover-riding
confidence deduction as a proxy for collective project uncertainty by assessing statistical
uncertainty in the forest carbon inventory and associated modeling.
The methodology monitoring section specifies that all analysis units will have representation
by one or more field plots. However, due to the difficulty of determining the independence
of plot data within individual homogeneous polygons (i.e. a specifically similar forest type,
site, and age), it will be necessary to only calculate a single carbon density observation for
each individual polygon sampled; either through the use of a single plot within that polygon,
or calculation of the mean of multiple plots within that polygon. Throughout these
calculations a plot observation, subscript i, is defined to represent the mean of all plots
within a given polygon.
The project-level uncertainty factor is calculated as follows:
Step 1 ‚Äì Calculate the average percent model error (E ) for the project based on the M
average area-weighted difference between measured values in monitored plot observations
and model-predicted values using Equations 60a,b. In the case where analysis units have
been used for stratification, the difference between the plot observation and model-
predicted value (both expressed on a per hectare basis) for a given analysis unit (y ) is d,h,i
weighted by the area of its associated analysis unit (A , )(Eq. 60a). The use of an area- PRJ h
weighting factor places more emphasis on analysis units that represent a relatively larger
proportion of the total project area.
E = 100 ‚Ä¢ (‚àë y / ‚àë(A , ‚Ä¢ y )) (60a) M d,h,i PRJ h m,h,i
Where,
The summation is across all plot observations, i, and across all analysis units , h;
y = A , ‚Ä¢ (y - y ) (60b) d,h,i PRJ h m,h,i p,h,i
E = Mean model error for the project (%) M
y = the area-weighted difference between measured and predicted carbon storage in d,h,i
analysis unit, h, plot observation, i (t C)
102

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
y = carbon storage measured in analysis unit, h, plot observation, i (t C ha-1) m,h,i
y = carbon storage predicted by model for analysis unit , h, plot observation, i (t C ha-1) p,h,i
A = area of project analysis unit, h (ha) PRJ,h
Step 2 ‚Äì Calculate the inventory error (E) at a 90 percent confidence interval expressed as I
a percentage of the mean area-weighted inventory estimate from the measured plots.
This methodology was designed to accommodate complex landscapes consisting of
hundreds to thousands of polygons, which can be further grouped into analysis units.
Inventory error is estimated based upon the difference between modeled and measured
values for monitoring plots established in polygons or in polygons grouped within analysis
units.
Inventory error, E, is estimated by first calculating the standard error of the area-weighted I
differences between the plot observation measurement and the associated model-predicted
carbon storage (both on a per hectare basis) for analysis units or polygons. The standard
error is then multiplied by the t-value for the 90 percent confidence interval. Finally E is I
expressed in relative terms (in Equation 60c) by dividing the 90% confidence interval of the
area-weighted differences between predicted and measured values in all plots by the area-
weighted average of the measured values in all monitoring plots.
E = 100 ‚Ä¢ [SE * 1.654 / ((1/N) ‚Ä¢ ‚àë(A , ‚Ä¢ y ))] (60c) I PRJ h m,h,i
Where,
E = Inventory error for the project (%) I
SE= the project level standard error of the area weighted differences between measured
plot observation and predicted values of carbon storage.
N= total number of plot observations in all analysis units or polygons28

context:
5.3.3. Ex Post Calculation of Net Anthropogenic GHG Emission Reduction
a) Technical description of the monitoring tasks.
The calculation of ex post net anthropogenic GHG emission reductions is similar to the ex-ante
calculation with the only difference that ex post estimated carbon stock changes and GHG
emissions must be used in the case of the project scenario and leakage.
b) Data to be collected.
Report the ex post estimated net anthropogenic GHG emissions and calculation of Verified
Carbon Units (VCUt, and VBCt) using the same table format used for the ex-ante assessment:
- Ex post estimated net anthropogenic GHG emission reductions and VCUs.
c) Overview of data collection procedures.
Data collection procedures are the same as described in previous steps. This step involves
compilation of data from previous procedures to calculate ex post net anthropogenic GHG
emission reduction.
d) Quality control and quality assurance procedures.
A map showing Cumulative Areas Credited within the project area shall be updated and presented
to VCS verifiers at each verification event. The cumulative area cannot generate additional VCUs
in future periods.
e) Data archiving.
All maps and records generated during project implementation will be conserved and made
available to VCS verifiers at verification for inspection to demonstrate that the AUD project activity
has actually been implemented.
All documents and records will be kept in a secure retrievable manner for at least two years after
the end of the project crediting period.
f) Organization and responsibilities of the parties involved in all the above.
203

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
All satellite imagery assessments will be performed by AVIX. CARBONEXT is responsible for
reporting and data archiving, and for providing assistance during verification audits. The Project
Proponent is co-responsible for data archiving.

PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM
FOR AFFORESTATION AND REFORESTATION PROJECT ACTIVITIES (CDM-AR-PDD) - Version 04
This component considers all plant material of the herbaceous and shrub-like type which is eliminated during
the establishment stages of the forest plantations: For the project conditions, the elimination of some coffee
shrubs in order to incorporate the forest system is estimated. The steps to be followed in the quantification of
emissions according to the methodology are:
Step 1: Estimate the amount of biomass removed. Said estimate is made in systems with existing non-woody
or shrub-like vegetation and for the pasture lands the maximum stock present is considered, in order to be
conservative. For coffee plantations it is carried out by counting the coffee trees eliminated per tree unit of
the tree stand model incorporated. The number of coffee trees removed is variable, given that their planting
density in the region ranges from 6,000 to 10,000 trees/ha. The biomass estimate per individual unit is carried
out through equations generated for the region are based on existing equations from the scientific literature
with data from the area51.
Step 2: Estimate the average biomass proportion harvested (with the information and procedures of step 1)
and apply the respective GHG emission factor. The emission factors established in Tables 3.A 15 and 3.A.16
of the IPCC GPG-LULUCF will be used.
Step 3: Estimating of GHG emissions resulted from the slash and burn based on revised IPCC 1996
Guideline for LULUCF and IPCC GPG-LULUCF (eq. 102, 103, 104 and 105 of methodology):
E = E +E +E (Ecn 102)

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
Estimation of carbon stock in living biomass of trees at the stratum level
1. The carbon stock in living biomass30of trees for stratum i (C )is estimated using the following trees,i,t
approach:
The mean carbon stock in above-ground biomass per unit area is estimated based on field
measurements in permanent sample plots by using the BEF method.
Method based on BEF
Step 1: Determine based on available data, e.g., volume tables (ex ante) and measurements (ex post),
the diameter at breast height (DBH, at typically 1.3 m above-ground level), and also preferably height (H),
of all the trees above some minimum DBH (in this case > 10cm) in the permanent sample plots.
.Step 2: Estimate the volume of the commercial (merchantable) timber component of trees-based on
available equations or yield tables (if locally derived equations or yield tables are not available use
relevant regional, national or default data as appropriate). It is possible to combine Steps 1 and 2 if field
instruments (e.g., a relascope) that measure the volume of each tree directly are applied.
.
Step 3: Choose appropriate values for BEF.
Step 4: Convert the volume of the commercial timber component of trees into carbon stock in
aboveground biomass via basic wood density D, the BEF and the carbon fraction using Eq. 5. See
Section VII for guidance on source of data for wood density.
Step 5: Convert the carbon stock in above-ground biomass to the carbon stock in below-ground biomass
via root-shoot ratio, given by:

4.4 Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
Net GHG emission reductions and removals in year t of the project are quantified according to
equation 59 in Section 8.4 of VM0026. The project‚Äôs contribution to the AFOLU pooled buffer
account is then calculated from annual project removals due to changes in soil carbon in
proportion to the non-permanence risk rating determined using the VCS AFOLU Non-Permanence
Risk Tool (equations 61/62). This buffer contribution is then subtracted from net GHG emissions
reductions and removals eligible to calculate the project‚Äôs final issuance of verified carbon units
(VCUs, VM0026 equation 60). These calculations can be found in the ‚ÄòEx Ante Emissions and
Removals‚Äô tab of the workbook ‚ÄòMIG Validation Emissions and Removals Calculations.xlsx‚Äô and
they are also summarized in Table 10.

4.3.3 Ex post calculation of net anthropogenic GHG emission reduction
a) Technical description of the monitoring tasks.
The calculation of ex post net anthropogenic GHG emission reductions is similar to the ex ante
calculation with the only difference that ex post estimated carbon stock changes and GHG
v3.3 177

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
emissions must be used in the case of the project scenario and leakage.
b) Data to be collected.
Report the ex post estimated net anthropogenic GHG emissions and calculation of Verified
Carbon Units (VCUt, and VBCt) using the same table format used for the ex ante assessment:
Table 36: Ex post estimated net anthropogenic GHG emission reductions and VCUs.
c) Overview of data collection procedures.
Data collection procedures are the same as described in previous steps. This step involves
compilation of data from previous procedures to calculate ex post net anthropogenic GHG
emission reduction.
d) Quality control and quality assurance procedures.
A map showing Cumulative Areas Credited within the project area shall be updated and
presented to VCS verifiers at each verification event. The cumulative area cannot generate
additional VCUs in future periods.
e) Data archiving.
All maps and records generated during project implementation will be conserved and made
available to VCS verifiers at verification for inspection to demonstrate that the AUD project activity
has actually been implemented.
All documents and records will be kept in a secure retrievable manner for at least two years after
the end of the project crediting period.
f) Organization and responsibilities of the parties involved in all the above.
All satellite imagery assessments will be performed by GEOWIKI. CARBONEXT is responsible
for reporting and data archiving, according to VM0015, and for providing assistance during
verification audits. The Project Proponent is co-responsible for data archiving.

4.2 Quantifying GHG emissions and/or removals for the baseline scenario:
The baseline net removals by sinks are the sum of the carbon stock changes in
carbon pools in the absence of the proposed ARR VCS project activity. As
demonstrated above in Section 2.5, the baseline scenario is the one involving
limited encroachment maintenance at a steady state. This baseline scenario
represents the carbon stocks in living trees at the start of the project activity
calculated according to the methodology with the formula:
61

VCS Project Description Template
For this ARR project activity, Face in 1999 commissioned Meijer to carry out a
baseline study whose results show that changes in the carbon stocks for both
above and below ground biomass are expected not to exceed actual net GHG
removals by sinks and are therefore assumed to be zero in the absence of the
project activity. Hence the formula above is only applied to multiply the 5.2 tonnes
of carbon per hectare (adjusted from Meijer, 1999), which is the conservative
value of the carbon stock in the stratum ‚Äòbanana plantation‚Äô, with the combined
area A of stratum ‚ÄòPlanted Area‚Äô and ‚ÄòRegenerating Area‚Äô. The total area to be i
planted during the crediting period is presented in Table 7.2 and has a size of
6,000 hectares. In addition, the Regenerating Area is 2,593 hectares. The
combined area is therefore 8,593 hectares. As the baseline is in a steady state,
there is no increases in GHG removals. See Annex III for details on the estimation,
and the spreadsheet ¬¥ Kibale Baseline Recalculation_082711 ¬¥, which details the
calculation of the mean tree carbon stock in the baseline, based on inventory data
by Meijer in 1999. In addition, the carbon stock changes in dead wood, litter and
soil organic matter are conservatively assumed to be zero based on the
methodology applied.

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
(3) Determination of EF BL, c
However, the baseline emission factor for continuously flooded fields without organic
amendments (EF ) can be determined ex-ante prior to the start of the project activity, in this BL, c
case, the ex-ante value should be used to calculate emission reduction during the crediting
period. It should be measured by using Closed Chamber in three reference fields which are
chosen in the project area.
According to the guidance on methane measurement in the appendix of AMS-III.AU Methodology,
the implementation of methane measurement in rice fields requires the involvement of experts
in this field or at least experienced staff trained by experts (i.e., from research institutions).
These guidelines cannot replace expertise in setting up chamber measurements. They rather set
minimum requirements that serve for standardizing the conditions under which methane
emissions are measured for projects under this methodology.
11 In the methodology, ‚Äúseason‚Äù means an entire cropping season from land preparation until harvest or post season drainage.
12 For all scaling factor used in this methodology, the average values in 2006 IPCC Guidelines for National Greenhouse Gas Inventories

Project Description: VCS Version 4.0
1. The Closed Chamber measurement requires the cooperation of the experts from Huazhong
Agricultural University and the staff of the Agriculture and Rural Affairs Committee of Jiang
District. Huazhong Agricultural University is a comprehensive agricultural research
institution directly under the provincial government. The expert set up the chamber
measurements on 3-May-201713. The base is embedded just before transplanting, and the
first gas sampling began on the second day after transplanting, followed by sampling every
7days. After sampling, as is stored in the evacuated vial, and the samples collected after
three times should be taken together for laboratory analysis.
2. Project proponent shall prepare a detailed plan for the seasonal methane measurements
before the start of the season. The plan shall include the schedule for the field and
laboratory measurements, the logistics that are necessary to get the gas samples to the
laboratory and a cropping calendar. The plan shall also include all reference field specific
information regarding location and climate, soil, water management, plant characteristics,
fertilizer treatment and organic amendments.
Project proponent prepared a detailed plan for measuring the EF before the start of the BL, C
season, which is provided in Table 4-1, Table 4-2, and Table 4-3 below.

Table 4-2 The plan for the seasonal methane measurements

was completed in September 2017.
14 Continuously flooded: fields have standing water throughout the rice growing season and may only dry out for harvest (end-season
drainage)

3.4 Net GHG Emission Reductions and Removals
Based on paragraph 43 of methodology AMS.I.D (version 18.0) and paragraph 61 of
methodology ACM0002 (version 16.0) and AMS.I.F (Version 03), net GHG emission reductions
are calculated as follows:
ERy = BEy ‚Äì PEy - LE y
ERy = Emission reductions in year y (tCO2e/yr)
BEy = Baseline emissions in year y (tCO2e/yr)
PEy = Project emissions in year y (tCO2e/yr).
LEy = Leakage emissions in year y (tCO2e/yr)
Since PEy = LE y = 0, Hnece ERy = BEy

As per methodology ACM0002 (version 17.0) and AMS I.D version 18, net GHG emission
reductions are calculated as follows:
ERy = BEy ‚Äì PEy

Ex-ante calculation (estimate) of net GHG emission reductions:
Ex-ante emission reduction calculations are calculated based on current project activity instances
to be included in the grouped project activity under consideration. Summary of ex-ante emission
